{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3415774,"name":"Carter Patterson","username":"Cartertheprogramer","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/8797f3/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-08-15T20:44:56.240Z","cooked":"

I am attempting to make a Path Planner program for a differential drive robot. I can not find any information on how I am supposed to use the information I get from the pplib command, and use it to drive the robot. I am using Talons for drive motors.

Are you using the AutoBuilder? Then you would just connect your drive method here if using Ramsete: Build an Auto | PathPlanner Docs

If you have the above setup, you’ll have to build the auto chooser.

Ours was something like this inside RobotContainer:

private final SendableChooser<Command> m_autoChooser;

public RobotContainer() { 
    configureNamedCommands();
    m_autoChooser = AutoBuilder.buildAutoChooser();
}

Making sure the NamedCommands string matches what you use in the the PP GUI.

private void configureNamedCommands() {
      NamedCommands.registerCommand("LaunchNote", shoot());
      NamedCommands.registerCommand("IntakeNote", intakeNote());
}

This should populate the autoChooser on your dashboard with whatever autos you are making in the PP GUI if they are in the deploy folder.

If I’m understanding your question correctly, I think there might be a tad of confusion here: When you setup the AutoBuilder, you supply the function that you use to drive the robot which it then uses to translate your paths into actual movements. No further code is required to allow it to drive. In this case, the AutoBuilder needs a function that accepts a ChassisSpeeds object:

image848×387 23.6 KB

I apologize if I’m missing something, but I think this might be what you’re asking.

Yes, I do not know how to take the drive function from the Auto Builder and drive the robot with it.

As written the output is in speeds and written as a consumer that is using that method reference (this::drive) to the drive method that can use the speeds to drive motors. At a glance, it isn’t always clear what values you have (chassis vs wheel speeds) to work with so making sure you have it setup to handle whatever is being outputted is necessary.

Anyways, sometimes it is helpful to search for example code that might cover what you are trying to do. I do that by picking some unique piece of code and searching Github, for example: Code search results · GitHub

Here is one of the results:

github.com

    2.

    4.

    5.

    6. 
          
  6.     this::setPose,
    7. 
          
  7.     () ->
    8. 
          
  8.         kinematics.toChassisSpeeds(
    9. 
          
  9.             new DifferentialDriveWheelSpeeds(
    10. 
          
  10.                 getLeftVelocityMetersPerSec(), getRightVelocityMetersPerSec())),
    11. 
          
  11.     (speeds) -> {
    12. 
          
  12.       var wheelSpeeds = kinematics.toWheelSpeeds(speeds);
    13.

    14.

    15.

    16.

    17. 
          
  17.         DriverStation.getAlliance().isPresent()
    18. 
          
  18.             && DriverStation.getAlliance().get() == Alliance.Red,
    19. 
          
  19.     this);
    20. 
          
  20. Pathfinding.setPathfinder(new LocalADStarAK());
    21. 
          
  21. PathPlannerLogging.setLogActivePathCallback(
    22.

Sorry, I think there’s still a bit of confusion here. PPLib’s AutoBuilder is requiring you to provide a method or function that takes a ChassisSpeeds object and takes care of pointing the wheels in the right direction and all that, just like you’d have when driving the robot from a joystick or controller. The idea is that you already have written this function, and all you have to do is supply it to AutoBuilder. AutoBuilder does not have it’s own drive function that you use, rather you have your own drive function that you give it to use.

Here is our team’s code which is using Y.A.G.S.L. which is a swerve drive library. That’s somewhat irrelevant to the matter at hand, just know that our code is going to look a bit different because we’re using Y.A.G.S.L. and swerve drive.

image1036×122 8.48 KB

This is our AutoBuilder up till the point where we tell it what our drive function is. (The bottom line that says m_swerve::setChassisSpeeds,)
Also note that we’re using configureHolonomic() instead of configureRamsete(). Again, that’s due to us using swerve, you don’t have to change that part in your code. In our case, Y.A.G.S.L. has a drive method that accepts a ChassisSpeeds object already, so all we had to do was supply that, along with some other methods Y.A.G.S.L. provides, to the AutoBuilder like you can see above.

Now, since you’re not using Y.A.G.S.L., you have to write your own function that accepts a ChassisSpeeds object which you can then supply to AutoBuilder by doing something like this::whateverYourFunctionNameIs.

If you are able to post your code here, preferably as a public GitHub repository, it’d be much easier to see what you’ve got so far.

I’m unsure why it would be doing that. Are you using a command-based project or not? If you’re not using command-based, just send your Robot.java file here. If you are using command-based, you probably have a DriveSubsystem.java file inside a “subsystems” folder, or a file with a similar name that has all the drive code inside of it. If that’s the case, send that file here instead of Robot.java.
